expanded_description: This section introduces scalars and vectors, two fundamental types of physical quantities. Scalars have only magnitude, while vectors have both magnitude and direction, making them essential for describing many physical phenomena like displacement, velocity, and force.

core_concept.principle: Physical quantities in physics can be classified as either scalars (with only magnitude) or vectors (with both magnitude and direction). This distinction is crucial because vectors require special mathematical treatment.
core_concept.explanation: Understanding whether a quantity is a scalar or vector determines how we measure it, record it, and combine it with other quantities. For example, adding forces (vectors) requires considering direction, while adding masses (scalars) is simple arithmetic.

image.alt: Diagram comparing scalar quantities (temperature, mass, speed) with vector quantities (force, velocity, displacement)
image.caption: Scalars have only magnitude; vectors have both magnitude and direction

sections.introduction: Scalar quantities are the simplest type of physical quantity. They are completely described by a numerical value and a unit, with no direction information needed.

key_concept.definition: A scalar is a physical quantity that has magnitude (size or amount) but no direction. It is fully described by a number and a unit.
key_concept.context: Scalars obey the ordinary rules of arithmetic. You can add, subtract, multiply, and divide them just like regular numbers, as long as they have the same units.

principles.statement: Scalars are completely specified by their size or amount - direction is not relevant.
principles.application: When reporting a scalar quantity, you only need to give the number and the unit.
principles.example: The temperature is 25°C. The mass is 5 kg. The time is 10 seconds.

principles.statement: Scalars follow the normal rules of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
principles.application: You can add scalars directly as long as they represent the same physical quantity with the same units.
principles.example: If you have 3 kg of potatoes and add 2 kg of potatoes, you have 5 kg total: $3 \text{ kg} + 2 \text{ kg} = 5 \text{ kg}$.

principles.statement: Scalars cannot have positive or negative signs indicating direction - though they can be negative in an algebraic sense (like negative temperature).
principles.application: A negative scalar simply means a value less than zero on some scale, not a direction in space.
principles.example: $-10°C$ means 10 degrees below zero, not a direction.

classifications.value: Everyday measurements that require no direction information

examples.explanation: The amount of matter in an object: 5 kg, 2.5 g, 1000 tons
Duration between events: 10 s, 3 hours, 45 minutes
Measure of thermal energy: 25°C, 300 K, 77°F
Capacity to do work: 100 J, 50 cal, 2 kWh
Rate of motion without direction: 60 km/h, 20 m/s
Total path length traveled: 5 km, 100 m
Space occupied: 2 L, 500 mL, $1.5 \text{ m}^3$
Mass per unit volume: $1000 \text{ kg/m}^3$, $2.5 \text{ g/cm}^3$

worked_examples.title: Scalar Addition
worked_examples.problem: A container has 2.5 L of water. You add 1.75 L more. What is the total volume?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Scalars with the same units add like ordinary numbers.

image.alt: Illustration showing various scalar quantities like mass, temperature, and time
image.caption: Scalar quantities are everywhere in everyday life

sections.introduction: Many physical quantities cannot be fully described by magnitude alone - they also require direction. These are vector quantities, and they follow special rules for combination and manipulation.

key_concept.definition: A vector is a physical quantity that has both magnitude (size) and direction. It is typically represented by an arrow whose length indicates magnitude and whose arrowhead shows direction.
key_concept.context: Vectors are essential in physics because forces, velocities, accelerations, and many other important quantities all have directional properties that affect how they interact.

principles.statement: A complete description of a vector requires both how much (magnitude) and which way (direction).
principles.application: To specify a velocity, you can't just say 20 m/s - you need to say 20 m/s north, or 20 m/s at 30° above the horizontal.
principles.example: A force of 10 N upward, a displacement of 5 km east, a velocity of 30 m/s at 45°.

principles.statement: Vectors are often represented graphically as arrows: length = magnitude, arrowhead = direction.
principles.application: In diagrams, vectors are drawn to scale so their relative sizes can be compared visually.
principles.example: A force of 20 N would be drawn twice as long as a force of 10 N in the same diagram.

principles.statement: Vectors do not add like ordinary numbers - direction must be considered.
principles.application: Two forces of 5 N each can add to anywhere from 0 N (if opposite) to 10 N (if same direction), depending on their directions.
principles.example: Walking 3 km east then 4 km north brings you 5 km from start (not 7 km) because the displacements add as vectors.

classifications.value: Quantities that require direction for complete description
characteristics: Specified by magnitude, unit, AND direction
Add using vector addition (not ordinary arithmetic)

examples.explanation: Change in position with direction: 5 m east, 10 km north, 3 m at 30°
Rate of change of displacement: 20 m/s north, 60 km/h southwest
Rate of change of velocity: $9.8 \text{ m/s}^2$ downward, $5 \text{ m/s}^2$ forward
Push or pull with direction: 10 N upward, 50 N at 20° to horizontal
Mass × velocity: $1000 \text{ kg·m/s}$ east
Force due to gravity: 500 N downward
Force per unit charge with direction: $100 \text{ N/C}$ to the right
Field with both strength and direction: $0.5 \text{ T}$ north

worked_examples.title: Understanding Vector Necessity
worked_examples.problem: Explain why force must be treated as a vector, using an example.

step_by_step.explanation: Imagine two people pushing on a box. One pushes with 100 N, the other with 100 N.
If both push the same way, the total is 200 N. If they push opposite directions, the total could be 0 N.
The same magnitudes give completely different results based on direction. Therefore, direction must be part of the description.

worked_examples.final_answer: Force requires direction because the effect of a force depends critically on which way it acts. Two equal forces can cancel or combine depending on their directions.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Vector quantities require direction for complete description because their physical effect depends on orientation.

image.alt: Illustration showing vector quantities with arrows of different lengths and directions
image.caption: Vector quantities require both magnitude (arrow length) and direction (arrow orientation)

sections.introduction: Vectors can be represented in several ways: graphically with arrows, mathematically with components, or using notation that indicates both magnitude and direction.

key_concept.definition: Vector representation includes graphical methods (arrows), mathematical notation (bold or arrow notation), and component form (breaking into perpendicular parts).
key_concept.context: Different representations are useful in different situations - graphical for visualization, components for calculation, and notation for clear communication.

principles.statement: Vectors are drawn as arrows: length proportional to magnitude, direction shown by arrow orientation.
principles.application: Use a scale (e.g., 1 cm = 10 N) and a protractor to draw vectors accurately.
principles.example: A force of 30 N east might be drawn as a 3 cm arrow pointing right.

principles.statement: Vectors are often written with special notation to distinguish them from scalars.
principles.application: In textbooks: bold face F or arrow notation $\vec{F}$. In handwriting: arrow over symbol $\vec{F}$.
principles.example: Force vector: $\vec{F}$ or **F**. Magnitude only: $F$ or $|\vec{F}|$.

principles.statement: Vectors can be broken into perpendicular components, usually horizontal (x) and vertical (y).
principles.application: A vector at an angle can be described by its x-component and y-component, which are scalars with signs.
principles.example: A velocity of 50 m/s at 30° above horizontal has components $v_x = 50 \cos 30°$ m/s and $v_y = 50 \sin 30°$ m/s.

process_flow.description: Decide how many units each centimeter (or inch) will represent.
process_flow.mechanism: Select a scale that makes the vector large enough to draw accurately but small enough to fit on paper.
process_flow.result: A scale like 1 cm = 10 N, 1 cm = 5 m/s, etc.

process_flow.description: Draw an arrow of the correct length at the correct angle.
process_flow.mechanism: Use a ruler for length, protractor for angle. Start at the tail and draw to the tip.
process_flow.result: A visual representation of the vector.

process_flow.description: Write the magnitude and any identifying information near the arrow.
process_flow.mechanism: Label with vector name ($\vec{F}$, $\vec{v}$, etc.) and sometimes the magnitude.

examples.explanation: $|\vec{F}|$ or simply $F$ represents the magnitude (scalar) of vector $\vec{F}$.
$\vec{v} = 3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j}$ means 3 units in x-direction, 4 in y-direction.
$\vec{v} = (3, 4)$ also means x-component = 3, y-component = 4.

worked_examples.title: Drawing Vectors to Scale
worked_examples.problem: Draw a vector representing a force of 40 N at 60° above the positive x-axis. Use a scale of 1 cm = 10 N.

step_by_step.explanation: Scale: 1 cm = 10 N, so 40 N requires $40 \div 10 = 4$ cm arrow length.
Draw x-axis (horizontal) and y-axis (vertical) intersecting at the tail of the vector.
From positive x-axis, measure 60° counterclockwise using a protractor.
Draw a 4 cm line at 60° from the x-axis. Add an arrowhead at the tip.
Label the vector as $\vec{F} = 40\text{ N}$ at 60°.

worked_examples.final_answer: A 4 cm arrow at 60° from horizontal, labeled appropriately.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graphical representation requires consistent scaling and accurate angle measurement.

image.alt: Diagram showing different ways to represent the same vector: arrow, components, and notation
image.caption: Vectors can be represented graphically, by components, or with special notation

sections.introduction: Breaking vectors into components is one of the most powerful techniques for vector analysis. Components allow us to use ordinary algebra with vectors by treating perpendicular directions separately.

key_concept.definition: Vector components are the projections of a vector onto perpendicular axes (usually x and y). The components are scalars (with signs) that, when added as vectors, give the original vector.
key_concept.context: Components simplify vector calculations because perpendicular directions are independent - you can work with x-components and y-components separately.

principles.statement: For a vector $\vec{v}$ with magnitude $v$ at angle $\theta$ from the x-axis: $v_x = v \cos \theta$, $v_y = v \sin \theta$.
principles.application: Use cosine for the adjacent side (x-component) and sine for the opposite side (y-component).

principles.statement: Components can be positive or negative depending on which direction the vector points along each axis.
principles.application: Right/up are usually positive; left/down are negative. Choose a consistent coordinate system.
principles.example: A vector pointing left has negative x-component; pointing down has negative y-component.

principles.statement: Given components $v_x$ and $v_y$, magnitude $v = \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2}$ and direction $\theta = \tan^{-1}(v_y/v_x)$.
principles.application: Use Pythagorean theorem for magnitude, inverse tangent for angle (pay attention to quadrant).

worked_examples.title: Finding Components from Magnitude and Angle
worked_examples.problem: Find the x and y components of a displacement vector $\vec{d} = 25 \text{ m}$ at 40° above the positive x-axis.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Components are found using cosine (adjacent) and sine (opposite) relationships.

worked_examples.title: Finding Components with Negative Signs
worked_examples.problem: Find components of a velocity vector $\vec{v} = 15 \text{ m/s}$ at 120° from positive x-axis.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Components automatically get the correct sign from the trigonometric functions based on the angle.

worked_examples.title: Finding Magnitude and Direction from Components
worked_examples.problem: A force vector has components $F_x = 8 \text{ N}$ and $F_y = 6 \text{ N}$. Find the magnitude and direction.

step_by_step.explanation: Both components positive, so vector is in first quadrant at 36.9° above x-axis.

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnitude = 10 N, direction = 36.9° above positive x-axis
worked_examples.concept_applied: The Pythagorean theorem gives magnitude; arctangent gives direction (with quadrant check).

image.alt: Diagram showing a vector broken into x and y components with trigonometric relationships
image.caption: Vector components are projections onto perpendicular axes, found using sine and cosine

sections.introduction: Understanding the differences between scalars and vectors is essential for correctly applying physical laws and solving problems.

classifications.value: How scalars and vectors differ in key aspects

examples.explanation: Scalar: number + unit only. Vector: number + unit + direction.
Scalar: ordinary arithmetic ($3 + 4 = 7$). Vector: special rules (can be $3 + 4 = 1$ to $7$ depending on direction).
Scalar: point on number line. Vector: arrow with length and direction.
Scalar: less than zero (temperature). Vector: opposite direction.

principles.statement: Speed is a scalar (magnitude of velocity); velocity is a vector (includes direction).
principles.application: A car can have constant speed but changing velocity if it turns (direction changes).
principles.example: A car going around a curve at 60 km/h has constant speed but changing velocity because direction changes.

principles.statement: Distance is scalar (total path length); displacement is vector (straight-line change in position).
principles.application: After a round trip, distance > 0 but displacement = 0.
principles.example: Walking 3 km east then 4 km west: distance = 7 km, displacement = 1 km west.

worked_examples.title: Distinguishing Scalars and Vectors
worked_examples.problem: Identify each quantity as scalar or vector: (a) 10 kg, (b) 20 m/s north, (c) 100 J, (d) 5 N downward, (e) 30 minutes.

step_by_step.explanation: (c) 100 J: energy has no direction → scalar
(e) 30 minutes: time has no direction → scalar

worked_examples.concept_applied: If a quantity includes direction, it's a vector; if not, it's a scalar.

image.alt: Diagram contrasting speed (scalar) with velocity (vector) using a car on a curved path
image.caption: Speed is scalar (magnitude only); velocity is vector (includes direction)

summary: Scalars and vectors are two fundamental types of physical quantities. Scalars have only magnitude (size) and include quantities like mass, time, temperature, energy, and speed. They follow ordinary arithmetic rules and are fully described by a number and unit. Vectors have both magnitude and direction, including quantities like displacement, velocity, acceleration, force, and momentum. Vectors require special mathematical treatment - they do not add like ordinary numbers because direction matters. Vectors can be represented graphically as arrows (length = magnitude, arrowhead = direction), symbolically with notation like $\vec{F}$ or **F**, or mathematically using components. Breaking vectors into perpendicular components ($v_x = v \cos \theta$, $v_y = v \sin \theta$) is a powerful technique that allows separate treatment of horizontal and vertical directions. Given components, magnitude is found using the Pythagorean theorem $v = \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2}$, and direction using $\theta = \tan^{-1}(v_y/v_x)$. Understanding whether a quantity is scalar or vector is essential for correctly applying physical laws and solving problems in physics.
